content: quote: SELMA, Ala. -- President Barack Obama's longtime minister, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright, gave an assessment Thursday of his former congregant's short time in the White House: Obama is just like any other president. Speaking in a brief interview with The Associated Press before giving a speech at a civil rights landmark, Wright smiled at the mention of the name of the nation's first black president. "He's like any other president," Wright said. "He's a politician and he's got to do what politicians do." . . "Barack's name ain't Jesus. Barack ain't gonna improve your child's reading score. There are things we've got to do on our own," he said. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/05/rev-jeremiah-wright-cautions-obama-aint-jesus/

There are things we've got to do on our own," he said. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/05/rev-jeremiah-wright-cautions-obama-aint-jesus/

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Glad you enjoyed it. I rather doubt that you'll ever determine "first use" so simply offered something "by way of a substitute". Here's another one if you are interested ... would seem to open up your search area to the international arena ... "http://themoderatevoice.com/26125/regarding-obama-as-a-messiah-does-him-no-favors-the-jakarta-post-indonesia/ Then, of course, there is this ... if one is a Louis Farrakhan fan ... Again, thanks for the links. When I was about 18 I witnessed a Bobby Kennedy drive through in my old neighborhood of Bensonhurst Brooklyn. He was in an open car, smiling and waving, and the crowd was absolutely bannana's. At the time I couldn't believe it... I mean I like the guy, but these people were absolutly crazy - I kid you not. I don't for a minute doubt that there are those who kiss the ground where Obama walks, and if they ever get their hands on his urine, will treasure it like holy water. But this is part of the time and the era we live in, and this Messiah business is basically phony Conservatives who have no other response than to throw phony rocks at him. I find it's use to be very offensive. Whatever critique I have of Obama, and I have many, he's NOT attempting a religious revival with himself as Jesus Christ. Dave

reply: Again, thanks for the links. When I was about 18 I witnessed a Bobby Kennedy drive through in my old neighborhood of Bensonhurst Brooklyn. He was in an open car, smiling and waving, and the crowd was absolutely bannana's. At the time I couldn't believe it... I mean I like the guy, but these people were absolutly crazy - I kid you not. I don't for a minute doubt that there are those who kiss the ground where Obama walks, and if they ever get their hands on his urine, will treasure it like holy water. But this is part of the time and the era we live in, and this Messiah business is basically phony Conservatives who have no other response than to throw phony rocks at him. I find it's use to be very offensive. Whatever critique I have of Obama, and I have many, he's NOT attempting a religious revival with himself as Jesus Christ. Dave
title: It's Official:  POTUS 44 Not the Messiah

content: quote: I find it's use to be very offensive. Whatever critique I have of Obama, and I have many, he's NOT attempting a religious revival with himself as Jesus Christ. I have no problem with that and I agree particularly with the emboldened part ... however some of his media and prominent political supporters, forget the little guys, did make such an attempt. If you are going to be offended at conservatives that play off of it, be offended as well by those of his supporters that create the linkage.

"He's like any other president," Wright said. "He's a politician and he's got to do what politicians do." . . "Barack's name ain't Jesus. Barack ain't gonna improve your child's reading score. There are things we've got to do on our own," he said. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/05/rev-jeremiah-wright-cautions-obama-aint-jesus/ I'd be curious to know who coined that term in the first place. The only people I've ever heard use it are anti-Obama. Sort of strange that they coin a term, and then play make believe... But then again, maybe there WAS some granny or grandpa who one day hysterically screamed out, "Obama is the Messiah," and Rush Limbaugh happened to be walking by... Dave

Again, thanks for the links. When I was about 18 I witnessed a Bobby Kennedy drive through in my old neighborhood of Bensonhurst Brooklyn. He was in an open car, smiling and waving, and the crowd was absolutely bannana's. At the time I couldn't believe it... I mean I like the guy, but these people were absolutly crazy - I kid you not. I don't for a minute doubt that there are those who kiss the ground where Obama walks, and if they ever get their hands on his urine, will treasure it like holy water. But this is part of the time and the era we live in, and this Messiah business is basically phony Conservatives who have no other response than to throw phony rocks at him. I find it's use to be very offensive. Whatever critique I have of Obama, and I have many, he's NOT attempting a religious revival with himself as Jesus Christ. Dave
